html:
Today I am aware of the relevant python bindings and check for them when removing or renaming functions.
It might be worth making the interface loosely coupled and also introducing a test suite of all interfaces to catch such changes.
text:
Today I am aware of the relevant python bindings and check for them when removing or renaming functions.
It might be worth making the interface loosely coupled and also introducing a test suite of all interfaces to catch such changes.

html: Regarding breaking changes such as the collision one, it really can’t be helped. The code is filled with these gotchas and it’s impossible to make changes if you worry about the data set. Going forward, @BenjamenMeyer wants to introduce api versions. Once that happens, I think we’ll refactor and release both data and engine, preventing such breaks.
text: Regarding breaking changes such as the collision one, it really can’t be helped. The code is filled with these gotchas and it’s impossible to make changes if you worry about the data set.  Going forward, @BenjamenMeyer wants to introduce api versions. Once that happens, I think we’ll refactor and release both data and engine, preventing such breaks.

html: One confession I have is that I too started at privateer and only moved after a few years to VS. things I’d like to see are at a minimum: graphics refresh - higher res gameplay and textures all around. A lot more side quests. I remember finishing the game and saying what now.
text: One confession I have is that I too started at privateer and only moved after a few years to VS. things I’d like to see are at a minimum: graphics refresh - higher res gameplay and textures all around. A lot more side quests. I remember finishing the game and saying what now.

html: Reading my own comment I’d like to clarify that it’s impossible to check for breaks on both games when coding. When releasing we should absolutely catch those.
text: Reading my own comment I’d like to clarify that it’s impossible to check for breaks on both games when coding. When releasing we should absolutely catch those.

html:
I think the PW dataset should match the VS one and solve it this way.
A lot of the crazy code in the engine is to account for weird stuff in the data.
One such example is shields. Units csv has eight facet shield support. There are no 8 facet shields in the game. There’s code to add the values of all front shields into the value of it.
As a rule, I think the data should align to the engine and not vice versa.
Obviously, when we switch to Json or yaml, some of these will be solved.
text:
I think the PW dataset should match the VS one and solve it this way.
A lot of the crazy code in the engine is to account for weird stuff in the data. 
One such example is shields. Units csv has eight facet shield support. There are no 8 facet shields in the game. There’s code to add the values of all front shields into the value of it. 
As a rule, I think the data should align to the engine and not vice versa. 
Obviously, when we switch to Json or yaml, some of these will be solved.

html: Running it is very similar to running VS:UtCS. You just specify the privateer_wcufolder as the data directory with -d, and to vegasettings with --target
text: Running it is very similar to running VS:UtCS. You just specify the `privateer_wcu`folder as the data directory with `-d`, and to vegasettings with `--target `

html:
OK. I reviewed @stephengtuggy 's PR and the original code is fine. I then took a look at the data, specifically troy.system. Nav 8 isn't a jump point, which is why it's treated as a planet. I don't think it's this change of mine that broke the nav point but the refactoring of system_factory. If you really want a temporary fix, it should be something along the lines of:

if(other_unit == PLANET && other_unit.gravity == 0) don't apply damage and force...

I can try and get to it later this week if no one else is available.
text:
OK. I reviewed @stephengtuggy 's PR and the original code is fine. I then took a look at the data, specifically troy.system. Nav 8 isn't a jump point, which is why it's treated as a planet. I don't think it's this change of mine that broke the nav point but the refactoring of system_factory.  If you really want a temporary fix, it should be something along the lines of:

`if(other_unit == PLANET && other_unit.gravity == 0) don't apply damage and force...`

I can try and get to it later this week if no one else is available.

html: This is obviously the solution. The same holds true for jump point (currently planets), ships (units), space installations (units), etc. It is a work in progress but I hope to get there in a few months.

html: Yes, they should definitely be separate unit types. Perhaps each data set could define its own set of unit types? Or would that be too complicated?
text: Yes, they should definitely be separate unit types. Perhaps each data set could define its own set of unit types? Or would that be too complicated?

html: Because unit types are really subclasses of unit, I think this would be problematic. If you implemented the code in python, it would probably be too slow.
text: Because unit types are really subclasses of unit, I think this would be problematic. If you implemented the code in python, it would probably be too slow.

html:
To be clear, this is an example of what I was thinking of:
unitTypes:
    Planet:
        visible: true
        hasGravity: true
        canBeCollidedWith: true
    Nav_Point:
        visible: false
        hasGravity: false
        canBeCollidedWith: false
    Jump_Point:
        visible: true
        hasGravity: true # ??
        canBeCollidedWith: false
    # ...
text:
To be clear, this is an example of what I was thinking of:

```yaml
unitTypes:
    Planet:
        visible: true
        hasGravity: true
        canBeCollidedWith: true
    Nav_Point:
        visible: false
        hasGravity: false
        canBeCollidedWith: false
    Jump_Point:
        visible: true
        hasGravity: true # ??
        canBeCollidedWith: false
    # ...
```

html: @stephengtuggy yes, we should add appropriate unit types to the engine that data sets can take advantage of. I don't think we'd have to declare them via your YML method like that, so much as it's a matter of what the data sets uses. It would be hard not to use NAV points; but one set might use Jump Points (PWCU) while another ignores them (VS:UtCS), etc. It's just a matter of what we make available.
text: @stephengtuggy  yes, we should add appropriate unit types to the engine that data sets can take advantage of. I don't think we'd have to declare them via your YML method like that, so much as it's a matter of what the data sets uses. It would be hard not to use NAV points; but one set might use Jump Points (PWCU) while another ignores them (VS:UtCS), etc. It's just a matter of what we make available.

html: @ermo I do believe their is a generic unit type; but it's been mixed up with all kinds of convergences of different types improperly. @royfalk has been breaking it down. We'll get to a good hierarchy eventually but it's going to take awhile to get there. We're making good progress though.
text: @ermo  I do believe their is a generic unit type; but it's been mixed up with all kinds of convergences of different types improperly. @royfalk  has been breaking it down. We'll get to a good hierarchy eventually but it's going to take awhile to get there. We're making good progress though.

html: I'd also add that a data set should be able to set different names for the unit types, possibly even using one unit type for multiple things if it makes sense in the same.

html: that sounds more like composability than class-hierarchy?
text: that sounds more like composability than class-hierarchy?

html:
class hierarchy defines the internal relationships and how we build the objects
composability - at the asset level - is how those objects are utilized
so in that sense, yes.
text:
class hierarchy defines the internal relationships and how we build the objects

html: the data sets should just be compositions of the functionality provided by the engine, no?
text: the data sets should just be compositions of the functionality provided by the engine, no?

html: I'm favour of composability.
text: I'm favour of composability.

html: I'm also in favour of data-sets being able to compose the features they need from well-engineered basic engine building blocks, as opposed to each game/data-set having their own engine.
text: I'm also in favour of data-sets being able to compose the features they need from well-engineered basic engine building blocks, as opposed to each game/data-set having their own engine.

html: But since I'm not the one doing the actual refactoring, I'm not going to pretend that what I think matters to any great extent. Mad props to those of you working to tame the beast and get it in ship shape with modern practices.
text: But since I'm not the one doing the actual refactoring, I'm not going to pretend that what I think matters to any great extent. Mad props to those of you working to tame the beast and get it in ship shape with modern practices.

html: As this is a 3D game, you don’t want composability to impact performance. Doing that is trickier than it seems, as I found out.
text: As this is a 3D game, you don’t want composability to impact performance. Doing that is trickier than it seems, as I found out.

html:
For example, it might generally have a Jump Point, but then it might have something special to create an alternate kind of thing (perhaps a one-off for the story line) that also behaves like a Jump Point enough it's desirable to just re-use it and call it something else.

I think that's more a virtualization of certain visible/internal properties baked into the exposed abstraction than a composability or even necessarily hierarchy question, if we want to have something that is of type FOO in the engine, but presents, and (in limited ways) behaves differently than other FOO objects due to certain data set parameters. More broadly, I'd say this is a question of what parameters are data-set exposed for specialization of instances beyond those that are necessary to otherwise instantiate a specific instance of a type, and/or that effectively define some properties of that type as happens-to-be-the-case-for-all rather than must-be-the-case-for-all (i.e. All FOO have property BAR=BAZ, but there isn't any logic that is only correct when BAR=BAZ, so I can allow the dataset to set BAR=QUUX for specific instances, if it so desires. This does require some forethought, so that planets-have-gravity or some other property that you want to make fungible doesn't get treated as a given; For instance, where planet-has-gravity is fungible, would need an explicit list of gravity-objects v.s. a list of planets, or would need to case-by-case each entity to see if it has gravity, etc. or else you can't let the dataset change the property because it's an actual invariant-as-the-code-is-written, etc.).
text:
> For example, it might generally have a Jump Point, but then it might have something special to create an alternate kind of thing (perhaps a one-off for the story line) that also behaves like a Jump Point enough it's desirable to just re-use it and call it something else.

I think that's more a virtualization of certain visible/internal properties baked into the exposed abstraction than a composability or even necessarily hierarchy question, if we want to have something that is of type FOO in the engine, but presents, and (in limited ways) behaves differently than other FOO objects due to certain data set parameters. More broadly, I'd say this is a question of what  parameters are data-set exposed for specialization of instances beyond those that are necessary to otherwise instantiate a specific instance of a type, and/or that effectively define some properties of that type as happens-to-be-the-case-for-all rather than must-be-the-case-for-all (i.e. All FOO have property BAR=BAZ, but there isn't any logic that is only correct when BAR=BAZ, so I can allow the dataset to set BAR=QUUX for specific instances, if it so desires. This does require some forethought, so that planets-have-gravity or some other property that you want to make fungible doesn't get treated as a given; For instance, where planet-has-gravity is fungible, would need an explicit list of gravity-objects v.s. a list of planets, or would need to case-by-case each entity to see if it has gravity, etc. or else you can't let the dataset change the property because it's an actual invariant-as-the-code-is-written, etc.).
